captions.text:
LARRY KOSILLA: What's
up, guys?
I'm Larry from ammonyc.com.

And one of the most common
questions I receive is how to

properly touch up your
car's paint.

In this episode, we'll discuss
how to resolve chip damage
caused by dings and rocks.

In addition to resolving the
unsightly chip marks, touch-up

primarily protects the paint
from future corrosion.

That's all coming up today on
this episode of "DRIVE CLEAN."
[MUSIC PLAYING]

LARRY KOSILLA: Detailing cars is
a very visual skill that I

learned by watching talented
artists in
their respective fields.

Our industry has several methods
for touching up cars.

Some techniques work better
than others, and some

professionals and weekend
warriors are more precise and

patient than others when it
comes to the application.

As you can see on the hood of
my car, the previous owner

should be commended for taking
time to touch up the rock
chips, but the result wasn't
necessarily visually beautiful.

Today I'm going to walk you
through the methods I'm most
comfortable using.

The process typically takes a
couple of days from start to

finish, so patience
is required.
It involves four steps--

assessing, prepping, application
and leveling.

But before we get started,
here's what you need--

touch-up sticks, 2000 grit
sandpaper, Carnauba wax,

rubbing alcohol, microfiber
towel, heat gun, No.

2 pencils, Crazy Glue, color
coat and clear coat, touch-up
paint and hole punch.

Step one is assessing the
damage to determine the
severity of the impact.

Does it need touch-up, or will
wet sanding be enough?

Proper touch-up is a long and
sometimes tedious process.

And if the impact can be
repaired by simply wet

sanding, I would avoid using
touch-up if at all possible.

Since these two areas are
missing clear-coat paint and

bare metal is exposed, touch-up
is our only option.

First I circle the area with a
paint pen to help find the

small chip quickly and to show
you the viewers at home where
we're working.

Next, it's important to clean
out the jagged and loose edges

of the existing chip
for two reasons.

The first one is you don't
want to put touch-up over

unsecure paint, because
it'll simply fall off,
defeating the purpose.

It's much like scraping flaky
paint off an old house before
the painting process begins.

The second is that by scuffing
up the bottom of the chip, the

touch-up that you will soon
apply will have better

adhesion because it's not a
smooth, slippery surface.

To do this, you'll need a pencil
with an unused eraser,

one 2000 grit sandpaper,
and a hole punch.

Cut out one piece of sandpaper
and remove it from the hole
punch reservoir.

This tiny perfect circle sits
atop the pencil's eraser with
a drop of Crazy Glue.

Be sure to affix the
sandpaper with the
gritty side facing outwards.

The purpose of this trick is to
only scuff up the chip and

not the surrounding area, if
possible, because we only want

touch-up within the
chip itself.

The number one reason why
touch-up has a tendency to

look bad is because it overflows
into the surrounding

areas that don't actually need
it, causing an uneven or bumpy

texture that is obvious
to the eye.

However, the pencil trick
focuses the repair precisely
where it's needed most.

The next step is a technique
I've used for years to help

corral the touch-up paint into
the scratch and to avoid the
non-chipped areas.

First, add a light layer of
Carnauba wax over the entire
area, including the chip.

Next, use rubbing alcohol on a
touch-up stick to clean out or
remove the wax from the chip.

You may need to do this several
times to ensure no

waxes remain on the exposed
bare metal.

The reason we do this is because
any waxed surface will

not allow touch-ups to stick
to it, which helps us avoid

the number one cause of bad
touch-up jobs, and that, of

course, is having touch-up
in the wrong area.

It also helps with the cleanup
process, because misplaced

drips can be wiped
away easily.

Now that the chip is clean and
ready to accept the touch-up,

we need to mix the paint and
clear-coat prior to the
application.

Add an even amount of color
and clear-coat.

Then mix in a small cup until
it becomes slightly thicker,

or more viscous than water, but
less viscous than syrup.

This can be very tricky, because
there's usually an

optimal 10 to 20-minute window
of time before the paint
becomes too clumpy.

Now, traditionally, color-coat
was added, dried, then

clear-coat was added
on top afterwards.

But from a practical standpoint,
this is not as

effective if your goal is to
have it look good as well.

I prefer to mix the color-coat
and the clear-coat together

prior to adding it to the chip,
because it's a healthy

balance between protection,
looks, and ease of
application.

To apply this new mixture of
paint and clear, I remove the

fibers from the touch-up stick
so that it's bare plastic.

You can use a razor blade or
simply bite off the end.

Next, dip the touch-up stick
into the paint so that there's

a small collection
at the very tip.

Your goal is to allow the paint
to flow into the chip

and to fill up the
cavity slowly.

The most common misconception
is that a
painting motion is needed.

It's best to actually dab and
push the paint around to help
it settle into the chip.

To speed up the drying process,
use a heat gun on low
for two to three minutes.

Keep touching the panel to make
sure it doesn't get too
hot during this process.

As the touch-up dries, it will
shrink, so additional layers

of paint will most
likely be needed.

This will take time, a
steady hand, and a
good deal of patience.

Next, wet sand the area with
2500 grit to blend the

surrounding paint, and notice if
it needs additional layers
of touch-up.

Use even pressure with a foam
or rubber sanding block.

This process will help expose
anything you may have missed
during the original touch up.

To remove the wet sand marks,
I'm using a microfiber cutting

pad, leveling fluid, and a
3-inch Rupes polisher.

Our goal is to see if we filled
in the chip or if it
needs additional layers.

Now, as expected, more touch-up
is needed to build up

the layers within the chip until
it's perfectly flat.

Repeat this process until you're
completely satisfied.

The touch-up process can take
one hour or one week,

depending on your tools,
skills, and level of

perfection required for
you to be satisfied.

The very last step, of course,
is to wax your car for
additional protection.

But always keep in the back of
your mind that touch-up is

designed to help prevent
premature corrosion and with a

bit of patience can make it
look much better, too.

The small chips on the front
of my car have been filled,

leveled and polished, all for
significantly less money than

if I had repainted it, and
I'm feeling pretty good.

For a PDF download of our
step-by-step tips on how to

touch up your paint, be sure
to visit ammonyc.com.
Well, that's if for me, guys.

Thanks again for watching
another episode of "DRIVE

CLEAN" right here on
the DRIVE network.

-Like this, and rip this
thing off, right?
OK, good.
See how it came off?
-Yeah, that's great.
[INAUDIBLE]

put it in your mouth
and bite it off.

-I have to put it in my
mouth and bite it off?
-All right, hang on.
Any second.
-There you go.
-If you ask me.
-There, bro, now you got it.

-Can you hold it up
just real quick?
-Now you're bad ass.

comments.author: lmadden6236

comments.text:
Wait, why no primer?  I'm thinking about touching up a few small dings on 
my car, but I'm worried about it as I've never done anything like this (at 
all) before.  I have a bottle of primer, one of basecoat, and one of 
clearcoat?  Is the primer unnecessary?? Or is he using a particular kind of 
paint that doesn't require primer? Or is primer only necessary for larger 
re-paint jobs, and not for tiny dings?﻿
comments.author: Ace Diamond

comments.text: Whats the maximum size area that this technique should be used on?﻿
comments.author: Hayden Lemire

comments.text:
Mixing clear and base coat is a bad idea. Rock chip spot came out lighter 
and it ruined my new Porsche 911. I should have applied base coat first, 
fill it with clear, then sand down polish. I should not have followed your 
recommendation on this one.﻿

comments.author: Amir Eghbal

comments.text:
+Amir Eghbal It helps to speed up the drying process, yes. You could opt 
out of the heat gun, but you are at the mercy of the paint drying time 
(don't forget atmospheric conditions, e.i. humidity, etc.).

comments.text: True.
comments.author: Rilly Jo

comments.text:
+Rilly Jo It surely looks good.  There could be a few variables.  Gray 
paint and a still camera won't show flaws like a darker paint will 
(especially in person while moving around).  Maybe quality of clear is a 
factor.  I wish I could give some more advice, but I'm still learning.
comments.author: AdamB5000

comments.text:
Ya obviously the machine will be better. I didn't want to get one cuz itd 
be a one time use. Check out that video I mentioned of buffing by hand by 
the user martin Wright. He did it by hand in about 15 minutes and looks 
flawless
comments.author: Rilly Jo

comments.text:
+Rilly Jo I'd comment further but I'm basing my responses on research and 
not experience.  I've actually never power buffed/polished, but plan to 
this spring.  I have about $500 of equipment in my Amazon shopping cart (in 
addition to what I already have on hand) and about 15 hours of research 
logged in the last week. :)   Cheers to Larry/AMMOnyc for his videos.  They 
are so informative.
comments.author: AdamB5000

comments.text:
O I c. Well after watching his video and a video called wet sanding and 
refinishing by hand, I attacked my car with the 2k grit paper, water, 
polishing compound, touch up paint and the regular wax and it looks ok. But 
these two guys ib the videos looked perfect. .especially the other guy who 
did it by hand
comments.author: Rilly Jo

comments.text:
A compound/leveling fluid after wet sanding will improve the finish.  It 
will help remove the dulling marks that come with wet sanding, but later 
following up with a polish will improve the paint further yet.

I believe his "leveling fluid" is his recipe of a typical compound.

comments.author: Terence Gardner

comments.text:
He fails to mention that if using metallic paint you SHOULD NOT mix base 
and clear coat prior to application; it dilutes the metallic shimmer in the 
base coat making the color darker and ultimately not matching well at all. 
Learned this the hard way myself touching up chips using this method. Has 
to sand original attempt out and start over. Big PITA. So, don't mix 
metallic and clear. ﻿
comments.author: Matthew Taft

comments.text: It was noticeably different with chips the size of a pen tip.

What is the disadvantage to simply overflowing the chip, and then wet

comments.author: AOS AIRSOFT

comments.text:
A single blob of paint probably wont blend and bond to the surrounding 
paint as well and will be more likely to fall off with future wear and 
tear. Plus, the extra sanding and polishing required is going to chew 
through more of the surrounding paint.

comments.author: Nathan Wilson

comments.text:
+Nathan Wilson if you want to spend $3,000 for a good respray then go for 
it... that is one way to have awesome paint all the time... I would rather 
just keep my current paint in great condition by doing things like this... 
claybar, glaze, sealants, waxes has kept my 1993 factory paint still 
looking new... and btw for the people who don't know he charges like $800 
for a full detail but that involves much much more then just paint 
detail/restoration... $50/hr for a specialty job is not very much, 
especially when you look into specialty mechanic shops they charge 
$120/hr...

comments.author: swansmeister

comments.text:
+bentleyboy58
shit thaught this was the gt40 vid, I replied on my smartphone on google 
and didn't knew it was about this vid. Nevermind then, but if it was my car 
I would get a respray. And yes an e34 m5 touring nurburgring 
package/edition is pretty rare, only 891 were build and even less with the 
nurburgring package. I rest my case.
comments.author: swansmeister

comments.text:
+swansmeister I'm sorry, I didn't know you were so passionate about knowing 
nothing about cars. If you think this is a Ford GT I shouldn't reply to you 
but since you are probably just too poor to get new glasses, i'll help you 
out. First of all, I would love to hear how you know 100% that Larry fixing 
a paint chip is more expensive than a respray, because that is the most 
retarded thing I've ever heard. Second of all, preserving the original 
paint doesn't necessarily have anything to do with the rarity or value of 
the car but is just a preference of the owner to keep the original paint. 
Lastly, there is no "fuzz". It's called doing it right. Maybe you should 
apply that to the work on your fictional rare cars.
comments.author: bentleyboy58

comments.text:
Did I say say anywhere a respray is cheaper, no I didn't but in case you 
want me to answer that for you, a respray would probably be cheaper then 
hiring this guy, actualy I'm 100% sure that this guy charges more money 
then a respray. Preserve the original paint of this car. Well first of all 
it's just a ford gt not a db5 or a ford gt70 or gt90 it's a stupid gt40. 
Second off all, there are many rare and much more expensive cars who had 
repays, never heard of 'paint by numbers' I even had a car more rare then 
this and got is resprayed by my lt expert , because the car was old and the 
color changed due to mother nature he took a little sample of the inside of 
my gasoline cap to match it perfectly. He just hires the guy cause he is 
dumb enough to do it and cause he thinks he is interesting. All this fuzz 
isn't necessary. You are the retard here so better shut your trap and get 
ya facts straight.
comments.author: swansmeister

comments.author: Chris Quach

comments.text:
yes you should prime any exposed metal prior to touch up application. 
 Clean the application area with a solution of 50/50 isopropyl alcohol and 
water.  Inspect the metal for any signs of rust. If there is rust, then you 
should apply a rust dissolver to the clean episode metal.  You can get rust 
dissolver at any auto parts store, such as Advanced Auto.  The rust 
dissolver neutralizes the oxidation process and removes surface rust to 
prevent it from spreading further.
comments.author: MrSierra5000

comments.text: +MrSierra5000 should i use primer first
comments.author: Angelaprincess

comments.text:
+Angelaprincess Seeing that you have bare metal exposed, then yes, you 
would need to apply touch up paint.  Depending on how particular about the 
finished result, touch up paint will most likely still be visible unless 
you're extremely careful and methodical in the application process.  If 
you're not willing to invest days or weeks to applying, leveling, 
reapplying, and leveling as many times as is needed for you to be 
satisfied, then you can always get it repainted.  This video shows how 
touch up can be applied to achieve show quality results, but as you can see 
the area he is applying touch up is very small.  The larger the area that 
has to be covered, the easier it will be noticeable to the naked eye that 
there was touch up applied. You need to assess the size of the scratches 
and determine if you want to try the touch up process or if repainting the 
area makes more sense.  Watch the video titled Best Paint Touch up tricks: 
Mercedes G55 by AMMO NYC.  This give you and example of touch paint to a 
large area and what a worst case scenario might look like with touch up 
applied.
comments.author: MrSierra5000

comments.text: +MrSierra5000 i see metal on my scratches, touch up paint do?
comments.author: Angelaprincess

comments.text:
+mikle65 You're right you can use touch up paint on scratches and chips 
that are not down to the metal, but touch up paint's primary purpose is to 
prevent corrosion.  If you simply wet sand the the chip or scratch to blend 
it with the surrounding paint, then compound and polish, you will get a 
much more pleasing result as far as looks are concerned.  I had a deep 
scratch on my hood that wasn't to the metal and simply wet sanded the 
surrounding paint to the level of the scratch and buffed and polished it 
smooth.  You can't tell there was ever a scratch there.  If I had filled 
the scratch with touch up it would have looked worse than just not doing 
anything.
comments.author: MrSierra5000

comments.text:
+MrSierra5000
doesnt have to be down to metal, if its down to base coat you cant use that 
method.
comments.author: mikle65

comments.text:
If the scratch isn't down to the metal, then it's possible to wet sand and 
polish without adding any touchup paint.  If metal is exposed, then touchup 
paint is required

comments.text:
One question I have is, when you are wet sanding or just sanding the area 
prior to touch up paint I noticed the eraser was bigger than the chip. 
Doesn't it scratch the paint that isn't chipped? I bought a 2012 really 
nice car and it has two nicks on the top and it appears the previous owner 
never did anything to it so it looks like it may have rusted in the nick. 
Don't I need to remove the rust prior to applying the touch up? I guess I 
never understood how sanding the area won't ruin the clear coat and or 
paint in the areas that don't need to be touched up around it. That is the 
one thing holding me back from doing this. Any help would be great! Thanks 
for the awesome video!﻿
comments.author: Steveo D

comments.text:
Sanding in general is a really aggressive process which is generally 
reserved for bigger scuffs in your paint like chips. Your car does have a 
limited amount of clearcoat and wetsanding does cut into the clearcoat 
moreso than polish or compoounding the paint. However, because you will be 
applying touch up paint, it will need to be sanded down to match the level 
of paint that is around the troubled spot so it will blend properly.

So for the most part, yes it will scratch the entire area that you are 
sanding. Just be sure to be gentle with the wetsand and do just enough to 
blend the area. You can fix the wetsand scratches by following up with 
applying compound via machine and then some polish.

comments.text:
You could probably use the "pencil sanding" method if the spot is small 
enough. From personal experience, I've been able to sand out 'most' of a 
bad touch up area, and retouch it with good results, even if there's still 
a bit of the touch up paint remaining. Of course, it really depends on how 
perfect you want it to be.
